Brucella rhizosphaerae was first isolated from the rhizosphere (the region of soil surrounding and influenced by plant roots) of various plant species.

The bacterium is known to be a slow-growing organism, and it exhibits characteristics typical of the genus Brucella, such as the ability to grow in the presence of thionin and basic fuchsin dyes. Genetically, Brucella rhizosphaerae is closely related to other Brucella species, but it is distinguished by its unique ability to thrive in the rhizosphere environment.

Brucella rhizosphaerae is considered an environmental Brucella species, as it has not been associated with any known human or animal disease. Its ecological role and potential interactions with plant roots or other soil organisms are still under investigation, but its discovery has expanded the known diversity within the genus Brucella.
